awd_titl_txt: Uncertainty Aware Routing in Stochastic Transportation Networks with Correlated Link Travel-Times
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop mathematical models and algorithms for enabling large-scale route planning tools that account for the uncertainty of travel-times on road networks.  The project addresses two major challenges. The first is to develop methods for converting very large amounts of historical vehicle trajectory data (e.g. where vehicles are at what times) into compact data representations. The approaches that are to be developed will account for real-time information (such as weather status), propagation in traffic congestion (accidents slow down nearby road segments) and user preferences (some drivers are less aggressive than others). The second stage involves developing route planning algorithms that will efficiently integrate these rich data models, and provide users with advanced route planning assistance. The project is expected to have strong educational impacts by providing undergraduate research opportunities, internships with industry, and research projects for graduate courses and projects. The outreach activities will target women and underrepresented minorities (including programs targeted at high school students) to expose them to cutting edge transportation research.

Enabling large-scale uncertainty aware route planning applications requires advances in the areas of probabilistic travel-time predictions using large-scale GPS-based vehicle trajectory data and stochastic routing algorithms for networks with correlated link travel-times. This project aims to solve a problem at the intersection of large-scale data modeling and routing algorithms in the context of transportation networks. From a technical perspective, this requires developing new models, work-flows and algorithms that span the areas of traffic modeling and prediction, machine learning, and algorithm engineering. The project will have a strong focus on developing computational tractable solutions, in the context of real-world applications, with the goal of enabling the deployment of these tools in practice through industry collaborations. It is expected that successful completion of the project will lead to further research on how the availability of such route planning tools can feed back into the system and influence network performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The high-level goal of this project was to develop mathematical models and algorithms for enabling large-scale route planning tools that account for the uncertainty of travel-times on road networks. The project addressed two major technical challenges that arise in this context. The first being the need to develop methods for converting very large amounts of historical vehicle trajectory data (time series of vehicle locations) into compact data representations. The approaches explored in this project account for real-time information (such as weather status), propagation in traffic congestion (accidents slow down nearby road segments) and user preferences (some drivers are less aggressive than others). The second challenge involved developing route planning algorithms that integrate this information about travel-time uncertainty and provide users with advanced route planning assistance.

The project led to new insights on modeling and estimation of travel time distributions for the purpose of route planning under uncertainty. Traditional travel-time estimation models for route planning provide independent travel-times at the link level. This leads to inaccurate travel-time distributions at the path level with erroneous means and overestimated variances. Intuitively, travel time correlation can be separated into two categories: (i) link-level correlation, which often occurs in the network portions which are highly prone to congestion, long delays and queuing, thus stretching travel times along successive links; and (ii) route-level correlation, which appears when distinctive driver habits, vehicle characteristics or global network effects have a similar impact on all the link travel times of the route. 

To capture the effects of congestion in (i), we consider an approximate model that satisfies the Markov condition, meaning that their distributions are conditioned on the realized travel time on the upstream neighbor via which each link is reached. Even though this representation does not exactly model the real network traffic dependencies, it is a significant improvement to the independence assumption and can be fairly easily added to popular routing problems without too much increasing the algorithms' complexity. We also address the situation raised in (ii) insofar as our model can adjust for general behaviors on the entire route by accounting for path-level variability caused by the driver, the vehicle or a global network effect. Furthermore, the link travel time distributions computed by our model do not only depend on the travel times on upstream neighbor links but also on time bins which divide the week and reflect distinct traffic patterns. In that respect, our model partially addresses the time-varying nature of link travel time distributions in real transportation networks. We also study the use of a well known Expectation Maximization (EM) based algorithm for estimating the parameters of such models, identify conditions under which it leads to degenerate results, and propose an algorithm update to address this issue. 

On the routing side, we also study the following optimal route learning problem. Consider a network where travel times on edges are i.i.d. over T rounds with unknown distributions. One wishes to choose departure times and routes sequentially between a given origin-destination pair across T rounds to minimize the expectations of: 1) number of rounds when the travel time exceeds an upper bound, and 2) summation over all rounds of the square of the difference between the given target and actual arrival times. We provide an efficient online learning algorithm for this problem. This work was published in the journal Operations Research Letters. 

This grant partially supported the research of two visiting (intern) masters students, a PhD student and a postdoc. One of the masters students working on the project was awarded a prestigious best internship award by Ecole Polytechnique in France for his work on estimating stochastic travel time distributions. The research conducted on this grant has also been presented at the Triennial Symposium on Transportation Analysis in 2022. 

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2023
Modified by: Samitha Samaranayake
